bEAPHx-w3.memHandModelNotes:
PMUs and AMUs should be selected inside the hydro buffer. Outside the hydro buffers, only select PMUs.   **The Management 10-25-06.   Mus should be selected outside water buffer in addition to within it. The stream buffer needs to be specified so that all riparian habitat is modeled, but phoebes may nest far from mapped water sources when using human structures which may be close to a small water source.  Thus ancillary and primary map units need to be selected within the stream buffer.  Forage in proximity to nests.  Nest sites are usually under solid cover such as rock outcrops, banks, buildlings and bridges.  Therefore the scale of habitat use is finer than that used for GAP analysis.  However nest structures can be inferred to be along streams in forest (provides a forest gap for foraging), in agricultural land near structures, and around rock outcrops.  The model should be interpreted as defining the habitat types phoebe's would use in proximity to nesting structures.  It may be possible to buffer intersections between roads and streams by 100m to predict habitat, however habitat could be under represented because building structures can not be identified.  The primary Mus are meant to reflect pixel Mus associated with nesting structures.

Removed water buffers - previouslu 120m from and into flowing and open water; 0 and unlimited into wet veg. Added 120m ecotone on Forest/Open edge types. MJR 25 June 2007.

references: Simpson M.B Jr. 1992. Birds of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Chapel Hill and London: University of North Carolina Press.
Kaufman K. 1996. Lives of North American Birds. Boston, New York: Houghton Mifflin Company.
American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.

Mitchell, W.A. 1988. Songbird nest boxes. Section 5.1.8, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Wildlife Resources Management Manual. Tech. Rep. EL-88-19. Waterways Experiment Station, Vicksburg, Mississippi. 48 pp.
Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
Hill, S. R., and J. E. Gates. 1988. Nesting ecology and microhabitat of the eastern phoebe in the central Appalachians. Am. Midl. Nat. 120:313-324.

Ehrlich, P.R., D.S. Dobkin, and D. Wheye. 1992. Birds in jeopardy:the imperiled and extinct birds of the United States and Canada, including Hawaii and Puerto Rico. Stanford University Press, Stanford, California. 259 pp.
Potter, E. F., J. F. Parnell, and R. P. Teulings. 1980. Birds of the Carolinas. Univ. North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill. 408 pp.
Harrison, H.H. 1975. A field guide to bird's nests in the U.S. east of the Mississippi River. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. 257 p.
Hamel, P. B. 1992. The land manager's guide to the birds of the south. The Nature Conservancy, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 367 pp + several appendices.
Ehrlich, P.R., D.S. Dobkin, and D. Wheye. 1988. The birder's handbook:a field guide to the natural history of North American birds. Simon and Shuster, Inc., New York. xxx + 785 pp.

Weeks, H.P., Jr. 1994. Eastern phoebe (Sayornis phoebe). In A. Poole and F. Gill, eds., The Birds of North America, No. 94. The Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia and The American Ornithologists' Union, Washington, DC.
Bent, A.C. 1942. Life histories of North American flycatchers, larks, swallows, and their allies. U.S. National Museum Bulletin 179. Washington, DC.
Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.
Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
